guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
Yes, that would be equally as retarded.

If you're not muslim, it's not up to you to speak the details of it, but you could aprove or not the entire religion. If you're not a christian, it's not up to you to discuss the details of the faith, but you could make an opinion in order to adhere or not.

The guy was talking about the date of manuscripts considering carbon-based dating. The same technique would deny everything else about the bible. Instead of discussing the details, BASED ON DIFFERENT PREMISES, the first thing should be to discuss these premises. In other words, to discuss if you will accept the entire bases of the faith or you will go with the principle that "science" would have the priority.

He is just a non christian talking about christianity for other non christians. It's a curiosity for them, but pointless if you actually are a real christian.
body_html:
Yes, that would be equally as retarded.

If you're not muslim, it's not up to you to speak the details of it, but you could aprove or not the entire religion. If you're not a christian, it's not up to you to discuss the details of the faith, but you could make an opinion in order to adhere or not.

The guy was talking about the date of manuscripts considering carbon-based dating. The same technique would deny everything else about the bible. Instead of discussing the details, BASED ON DIFFERENT PREMISES, the first thing should be to discuss these premises. In other words, to discuss if you will accept the entire bases of the faith or you will go with the principle that "science" would have the priority.

He is just a non christian talking about christianity for other non christians. It's a curiosity for them, but pointless if you actually are a real christian.

body: If Enoch is authentic it would have had to be carried with Noah on the ark, possibly translated into Sumerian if it wasn't already and passed on to Abraham and Joseph, then translated into Hebrew and preserved during the Egyptian captivity and on the exodus, then copied over the many centuries by the lying pens of scribes, then translated into Greek which is what the other translations are based on, then finally translated into Ethiopian which is the form we have today. It's very difficult for it to have been passed along those lines, and even if it did the quality of the text is hopeless.
body_html: If Enoch is authentic it would have had to be carried with Noah on the ark, possibly translated into Sumerian if it wasn't already and passed on to Abraham and Joseph, then translated into Hebrew and preserved during the Egyptian captivity and on the exodus, then copied over the many centuries by the lying pens of scribes, then translated into Greek which is what the other translations are based on, then finally translated into Ethiopian which is the form we have today. It's very difficult for it to have been passed along those lines, and even if it did the quality of the text is hopeless.

body: Oral tradition, the way everything was passed down in ancient times. Genesis is an interesting book, as it is not one single narrative but a collection of many different writings about pre-Mosaic times, which sometimes conflict with each other (see the two very different creation stories in Genesis 1 and Genesis 2 for example) but generally show a solid timeline. The earliest parts of it are actually corrected versions of Sumerian texts, who lived immediately after the flood and were aware of the creation and flood, and recorded it (albeit a corrupted pagan version) thousands of years earlier in the Sumerian language, which was probably Abraham's mother tongue (parts of these texts are extant today in excavated tablets). This is one step of translation and transmission from corrupted Sumerian to corrected Hebrew (maybe one or two more depending on how Noah got his information) but Enoch would've had to go through way more of them, at least 2 or 3 already if we had it in Hebrew, and we only have the Ethiopic translation which itself was not even translated from the Hebrew text, but from an earlier Greek translation of this Hebrew! It's difficult to think the book could've been copied since pre-flood times, especially given that writing seems to have been invented by the enslaved Hebrews in Egypt, but even if it had been the text in our possession is so unreliable that it's probably not even worth reading. The scribes have damaged the main biblical books enough already, imagine what 2-3 times as many centuries and 3-4 translations away from the original is like.
body_html: Oral tradition, the way everything was passed down in ancient times. Genesis is an interesting book, as it is not one single narrative but a collection of many different writings about pre-Mosaic times, which sometimes conflict with each other (see the two very different creation stories in Genesis 1 and Genesis 2 for example) but generally show a solid timeline. The earliest parts of it are actually corrected versions of Sumerian texts, who lived immediately after the flood and were aware of the creation and flood, and recorded it (albeit a corrupted pagan version) thousands of years earlier in the Sumerian language, which was probably Abraham's mother tongue (parts of these texts are extant today in excavated tablets). This is one step of translation and transmission from corrupted Sumerian to corrected Hebrew (maybe one or two more depending on how Noah got his information) but Enoch would've had to go through way more of them, at least 2 or 3 already if we had it in Hebrew, and we only have the Ethiopic translation which itself was not even translated from the Hebrew text, but from an earlier Greek translation of this Hebrew! It's difficult to think the book could've been copied since pre-flood times, especially given that writing seems to have been invented by the enslaved Hebrews in Egypt, but even if it had been the text in our possession is so unreliable that it's probably not even worth reading. The scribes have damaged the main biblical books enough already, imagine what 2-3 times as many centuries and 3-4 translations away from the original is like.
